<table><thead><tr><th>Prefix</th><th>Symbol</th><th>Multiplication Factor</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>exa</td><td>E</td><td>1018</td><td>= 1 000 000 000 000 000 000</td></tr><tr><td>peta</td><td>P</td><td>1015</td><td>= 1 000 000 000 000 000</td></tr><tr><td>tera</td><td>T</td><td>1012</td><td>= 1 000 000 000 000</td></tr><tr><td>giga</td><td>G</td><td>109</td><td>= 1 000 000 000</td></tr><tr><td>mega</td><td>M</td><td>106</td><td>= 1 000 000</td></tr><tr><td>kilo</td><td>k</td><td>103</td><td>= 1 000</td></tr><tr><td>hector</td><td>h</td><td>102</td><td>= 100</td></tr><tr><td>deca</td><td>da</td><td>101</td><td>= 10</td></tr><tr><td>deci</td><td>d</td><td>10-1</td><td>= 0.1</td></tr><tr><td>centi</td><td>c</td><td>10-2</td><td>= 0.01</td></tr><tr><td>milli</td><td>m</td><td>10-3</td><td>= 0.001</td></tr><tr><td>micro</td><td>μ</td><td>10-6</td><td>= 0.000 001</td></tr><tr><td>nano</td><td>n</td><td>10-9</td><td>= 0.000 000 001</td></tr><tr><td>pico</td><td>p</td><td>10-12</td><td>= 0.000 000 000 001</td></tr><tr><td>femto</td><td>f</td><td>10-15</td><td>= 0.000 000 000 000 001</td></tr><tr><td>atto</td><td>a</td><td>10-18</td><td>= 0.000 000 000 000 000 001</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="module-two">MODULE TWO<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#module-two" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-1-d-c-current">2.1 D.C. CURRENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-1-d-c-current" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Direct current (DC) is the unidirectional flow of electric charge. The electric charge flows in only one direction, steadily or in pulse. A battery is a good example of a DC power supply.</p>
<p>DC circuit, electrons emerge from the negative, or minus, pole and move towards the positive, or plus, pole. Nevertheless, physicists define DC as traveling from plus to minus. Virtually all electronic and computer hardware needs DC to function. Most solid-state equipment requires between 1.5 and 13.5 volts.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-9b6334e8.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg">
Fig 2.1: Direct Current</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-2-the-analogy-between-current-flow-and-water-flow">2.2 The Analogy between Current Flow and Water Flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-2-the-analogy-between-current-flow-and-water-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When describing voltage, current, and resistance, a common analogy is a water tank. In this analogy, charge is represented by the water amount, voltage is represented by the water pressure, and current is represented by the water flow. So for this analogy, remember:</p>
<p>Water = Charge</p>
<p>Pressure = Voltage</p>
<p>Flow = Current</p>
<p>The pressure at the end of the hose can represent voltage. The water in the tank represents charge. The more water in the tank, the higher the charge, the more pressure is measured at the end of the hose. We can think of this tank as a battery, a place where we store a certain amount of energy and then release it. If we drain our tank a certain amount, the pressure created at the end of the hose goes down. There is also a decrease in the amount of water that will flow through the hose. Less pressure means less water is flowing, which brings us to current.</p>
<p>Consider a water tank at a certain height above the ground. At the bottom of this tank there is a hose.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-0d27b5d1.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg">
Fig 2.2: Analogy between Current Flow and Water Flow</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-4-constant-current-source">2.4 Constant Current Source<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-4-constant-current-source" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A voltage source that has very high internal impedance as compared with external load impedance is considered as a constant current source. The load current nearly remains the same when the output voltage changes.</p>
<p>A d.c. source of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1000\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  with internal resistance  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>900</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R = 900\mathrm{k}\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">900</span><span class="mord mathrm">k</span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span> . Here, load  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span></span>  varies over 3: 1 range from  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50\mathrm{k}\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord mathrm">k</span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span>  to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>150</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">150\mathrm{k}\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mord mathrm">k</span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span> . Over this variation of load  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi><mi>L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">RL</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span></span></span></span></span> , the circuit current  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span></span></span></span></span>  is essentially constant at 1.05 to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.95</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.95\mathrm{mA}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.95</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mA</span></span></span></span></span></span>  or approximately  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{mA}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mA</span></span></span></span></span></span> . It may be noted that output voltage  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  varies approximately in the same 3: 1 range as  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi><mi>L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">RL</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span></span></span></span></span> , although load current essentially remains constant at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{mA}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mA</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>The example of a constant current source is found in vacuum tube circuits where the tube acts as a generator having internal resistance as high as  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{M}\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm">M</span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span> . The following points may be noted regarding the constant current source:</p>
<p>(i) Due to high internal resistance of the source, the load current remains essentially constant as the load R is varied.
(ii) The output voltage varies approximately in the same range as RL, although current remains constant.
(iii) The output voltage  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  is much less than the generated voltage  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span></span></span></span></span>  because of high IR drop.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="example-1">Example 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>A d.c. source generating  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>500</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">500\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  has an internal resistance of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1000\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1000Ω</span></span></span></span></span> . Find the load current if load resistance is</li>
</ol>
<p>i.  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10Ω</span></span></span></span></span>
ii.  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">50Ω</span></span></span></span></span>  and
iii.  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">100Ω</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-4-ohm-s-law">2.4 OHM'S LAW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-4-ohm-s-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The relationship between Voltage, Current and Resistance in any DC electrical circuit was firstly discovered by the German physicist Georg Ohm.</p>
<p>Georg Ohm a German physicist found that, at a constant temperature, the electrical current flowing through a fixed linear resistance is directly proportional to the voltage applied across it, and also inversely proportional to the resistance. This relationship between the Voltage, Current and Resistance forms the basis of Ohms Law and is shown below.</p>
<p>Ohm's law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the voltage across the two points.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>V</mi><mi>R</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I = \frac {V}{R}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0463em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Where  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span></span></span></span></span>  is the current through the conductor in units of amperes,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  is the voltage measured across the conductor in units of volts, and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span></span>  the constant of proportionality is resistance of the conductor in units of ohms. More specifically, Ohm's law states that the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span></span>  in this relation is constant, independent of the current. Ohm's Law Triangle is given as;</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-e191d480.jpeg" alt="img-24.jpeg">
Fig 2.3: Ohm's Law Triangle</p>
<p>Then by using Ohms Law we can see that a voltage of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  applied to a resistor of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1Ω</span></span></span></span></span>  will cause a current of 1A to flow and the greater the resistance value, the less current that will flow for a given</p>
<p>applied voltage. Any Electrical device or component that obeys "Ohms Law" that is, the current flowing through it is proportional to the voltage across it (I  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>  V), such as resistors or cables, are said to be "Ohmic" or "linear" in nature, and devices that do not, such as transistors or diodes, are said to be "Non-ohmic" devices.</p>
<p>Ohm's Law can be used to solve simple circuits. A complete circuit is one which is a closed loop. It contains at least one source of voltage (thus providing an increase of potential energy), and at least one potential drop i.e., a place where potential energy decreases. The sum of the voltages around a complete circuit is zero.</p>
<p>An increase of potential energy in a circuit causes a charge to move from a lower to a higher potential (ie. voltage). Note the difference between potential energy and potential. Because of the electrostatic force, which tries to move a positive charge from a higher to a lower potential, there must be another 'force' to move charge from a lower potential to a higher inside the battery. This so-called force is called the electromotive force, or emf. The SI unit for the emf, E is a volt. The symbol  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="script">E</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathcal{E}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathcal" style="margin-right: 0.08944em;">E</span></span></span></span></span> , represents the emf.</p>
<p>A decrease of potential energy can occur by various means. For example, heat lost in a circuit due to some electrical resistance could be one source of energy drop. Because energy is conserved, the potential difference across an emf must be equal to the potential difference across the rest of the circuit. That is, Ohm's Law will be satisfied:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>ξ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\xi = I R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.04601em;">ξ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-5-practice-problems">2.5 Practice Problems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-5-practice-problems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A circuit with a source voltage of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>12</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">12\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">12</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  DC and a circuit resistance of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>150</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">150\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">150Ω</span></span></span></span></span> . Solve for the unknown using Ohm's Law.</p>
</li>
<li></li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3316872e.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-38b06ce3.jpeg" alt="img-26.jpeg"></p>
<ol start="4">
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mtext>  </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>55</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{I} = 2\mathrm{\;A},\mathrm{R} = {55}\mathrm{{ohms}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">I</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">55</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ohms</span></span></span></span></span></span>  . What is the value of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">E</span></span></span></span></span>  ?</li>
<li>A Resistance of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">15Ω</span></span></span></span></span>  carries a current of 5Amps. Calculate the voltage developed across the resistor.</li>
<li>Calculate the resistance of an iron filament if it operates on  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>230</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">230\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">230</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  supply and draws a current equal to 2Amp.</li>
<li>
<ol>
<li>A toaster oven is plugged into an outlet that provides a voltage difference of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>120</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">120\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">120</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span> . What power does the oven use if the current is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span> ?</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<ol start="2">
<li>A VCR that is not playing still uses  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10.0\mathrm{W}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10.0</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">W</span></span></span></span></span>  of power. What is the current if the VCR is plugged into a  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>120</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">120\mathrm{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">120</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span></span></span></span></span>  electric outlet?</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<ol start="3">
<li>A flashlight bulb uses  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.4\mathrm{W}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2.4</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">W</span></span></span></span></span>  of power when the current in the bulb is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.8</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.8\mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.8</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span> . What is the voltage difference?</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<ol start="4">
<li>A refrigerator operates on average for  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>h</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10.0 \, \text{h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">10.0</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">h</span></span></span></span></span></span>  a day. If the power rating of the refrigerator is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>700</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>W</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">700 \, \text{W}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">700</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">W</span></span></span></span></span></span> , how much electrical energy does the refrigerator use in 1 day? (make sure to convert to kW)</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-6-electrical-power-in-circuits">2.6 Electrical Power in Circuits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-electrical-power-in-circuits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Electrical Power, (P) in a circuit is the rate at which energy is absorbed or produced within a circuit. A source of energy such as a voltage will produce or deliver power while the connected load absorbs it. Light bulbs and heaters for example, absorb electrical power and convert it into either heat, or light, or both. The higher their value or rating in watts the more electrical power they are likely to consume.</p>
<p>The quantity symbol for power is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">P</span></span></span></span></span>  and is the product of voltage multiplied by the current with the unit of measurement being the Watt (W). Prefixes are used to denote the various multiples or sub-multiples of a watt, such as: milliwatts ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{mW} = 10^{-3}\mathrm{W}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mW</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">W</span></span></span></span></span> ) or kilowatts ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{kW} = 10^{3}\mathrm{W}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kW</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">W</span></span></span></span></span> ).</p>
<p>Then by using Ohm's law and substituting for the values of V, I and R the formula for electrical power can be found as:</p>
<p>Power (P)  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">w</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>×</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P(watts) = V(volts) \times I(amps)}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">watts</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">volts</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">I</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">amps</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mo>×</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P = V \times I}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">I</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Also:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">w</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>÷</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P(watts) = V^2(volts)\div R(\Omega)}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">watts</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">volts</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">÷</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">Ω</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>÷</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P = V^2\div R}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8974em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">÷</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Also:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">w</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>×</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P(watts) = I^2(amps) \times R(\Omega)}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">watts</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">amps</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathrm">Ω</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P = I^2 \times R}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8974em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-4ace4c66.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg">
Fig 2.4: Power Triangle</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-6-1-electrical-power-rating">2.6.1 Electrical Power Rating<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-1-electrical-power-rating" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Electrical components are given a "power rating" in watts that indicates the maximum rate at which the component converts the electrical power into other forms of energy such as heat, light or motion. For example, a 1/4W resistor, a 100W light bulb etc.</p>
<p>Electrical devices convert one form of power into another. So for example, an electrical motor will covert electrical energy into a mechanical force, while an electrical generator converts mechanical force into electrical energy. A light bulb converts electrical energy into both light and heat.</p>
<p>Also, we now know that the unit of power is the WATT, but some electrical devices such as electric motors have a power rating in the old measurement of "Horsepower" or hp. The relationship between horsepower and watts is given as:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>746</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{hp} = 746\mathrm{W}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">hp</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">746</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">W</span></span></span></span></span> . So for example, a two-horsepower motor has a rating of 1492W, (2 x 746) or 1.5kW.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-7-resistivity">2.7 Resistivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-7-resistivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Electrical resistivity (also known as specific electrical resistance or volume resistivity) is a fundamental property of a material that quantifies how strongly that material opposes the flow of</p>
<p>electric current. A low resistivity indicates a material that readily allows the flow of electric current. Resistivity is commonly represented by the Greek letter  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ρ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rho</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ρ</span></span></span></span></span>  (rho). The SI unit of electrical resistivity is the ohm-metre ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\Omega \cdot \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">Ω</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> ). Resistivity of materials is the resistance to the flow of an electric current with some materials resisting the current flow more than others</p>
<p>Ohms Law states that when a voltage (V) source is applied between two points in a circuit, an electrical current (I) will flow between them encouraged by the presence of the potential difference between these two points. The amount of electrical current which flows is restricted by the amount of resistance (R) present. In other words, the voltage encourages the current to flow (the movement of charge), but it is resistance that discourages it.</p>
<p>We always measure electrical resistance in Ohms, where Ohms is denoted by the Greek letter Omega,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span> . So for example:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">50Ω</span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\mathrm{k}\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord mathrm">k</span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4.7</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4.7\mathrm{M}\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">4.7</span><span class="mord mathrm">M</span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span> , etc. Conductors (e.g. wires and cables) generally have very low values of resistance (less than  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1Ω</span></span></span></span></span> ) and thus we can neglect them as we assume in circuit analysis calculations that wires have zero resistance. Insulators (e.g. plastic or air) on the other hand generally have very high values of resistance (greater than  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50\mathrm{M}\Omega</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord mathrm">M</span><span class="mord">Ω</span></span></span></span></span> ), therefore we can ignore them also for circuit analysis as their value is too high.</p>
<p>The electrical resistance between two points can depend on many factors such;</p>
<p>i. as the conductors length,
ii. its cross-sectional area,
iii. the temperature,
iv. the actual material from which it is made.</p>
<p>For example, let's assume we have a piece of wire (a conductor) that has a length  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">L</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span></span></span></span></span> , a cross-sectional area  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span></span></span></span></span>  and a resistance  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span></span>  as shown.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-b212bc90.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg">
Fig 2.5: Resistivity of L Length Conductor</p>
<p>The electrical resistance, R of this simple conductor is a function of its length, L and the conductors area, A. Ohms law tells us that for a given resistance R, the current flowing through the conductor</p>
<p>is proportional to the applied voltage as  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{I} = \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{R}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">I</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span></span></span></span></span> . Now suppose we connect two identical conductors together in a series combination as shown.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251222-3fe92ba3.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg">
Fig 2.6: Resistivity of 2L Length Conductor</p>
<p>By connecting the two conductors together in a series combination, that is end to end, we have effectively doubled the total length of the conductor (2L), while the cross-sectional area A, remains exactly the same as before. But as well as doubling the length, we have also doubled the total resistance of the conductor, giving 2R as:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{R} + 1\mathrm{R} = 2\mathrm{R}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>Therefore we can see that the resistance of the conductor is proportional to its length, that is:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">R</mi><mo>∝</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{R} \propto \mathbf{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">L</span></span></span></span></span> . In other words, we would expect the electrical resistance of a conductor (or wire) to be proportionally greater the longer it is.</p>
<p>Note also that by doubling the length and therefore the resistance of the conductor (2R), to force the same current,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6595em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">i</span></span></span></span></span>  to flow through the conductor as before, we need to double (increase) the applied voltage as now  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>R</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I = (2V) / (2R)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> . Suppose we connect the two identical conductors together in parallel combination, we have effectively doubled the total area giving 2A, while the conductor's length, L remains the same as the original single conductor. But as well as doubling the area, by connecting the two conductors together in parallel we have effectively halved the total resistance of the conductor, giving 1/2R as now each half of the current flows through each conductor branch.</p>
<p>Thus the resistance of the conductor is inversely proportional to its area, that is:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">R</mi><mn mathvariant="bold">1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo>∝</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{R} \mathbf{1} / \propto \mathbf{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">R1</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">A</span></span></span></span></span> , or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>∝</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{R} \propto 1 / \mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span> . In other words, we would expect the electrical resistance of a conductor (or wire) to be proportionally less the greater is its cross-sectional area. Also by doubling the area and therefore halving the total resistance of the conductor branch (1/2R), for the same current,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">i</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6595em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">i</span></span></span></span></span>  to flow through the parallel conductor branch as before we only need half (decrease) the applied voltage as now  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{I} = (1 / 2\mathrm{V}) / (1 / 2\mathrm{R})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">I</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">1/2</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">V</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">1/2</span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>So hopefully we can see that the resistance of a conductor is directly proportional to the length (L) of the conductor, that is:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>∝</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{R} \propto \mathrm{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span></span></span></span> , and inversely proportional to its area (A),  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>∝</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{R} \propto 1 / \mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span> . Thus we can correctly say that resistance is:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mfrac><mi>l</mi><mi>A</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R = \rho \frac {l}{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ρ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.01968em;">l</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Where: R is the resistance in ohms (Ω), L is the length in metres (m), A is the area in square metres (m²), and where the proportional constant ρ (the Greek letter "rho") is known as Resistivity.</p>
<p>The electrical resistivity of a particular conductor material is a measure of how strongly the material opposes the flow of electric current through it. This resistivity factor, sometimes called its "specific electrical resistance", enables the resistance of different types of conductors to be compared to one another at a specified temperature according to their physical properties without regards to their lengths or cross-sectional areas. Thus the higher the resistivity value of ρ the more resistance and vice versa.</p>
<p>For example, the resistivity of a good conductor such as copper is on the order of 1.72 × 10⁻⁸ ohm metre (or 17.2 nΩm), whereas the resistivity of a poor conductor (insulator) such as air can be well over 1.5 × 10¹⁴ or 150 trillion Ωm.</p>
<p>Materials such as copper and aluminium are known for their low levels of resistivity thus allowing electrical current to easily flow through them making these materials ideal for making electrical wires and cables. Silver and gold have much low resistivity values, but for obvious reasons are more expensive to turn into electrical wires.</p>
<p>Then the factors which affect the resistance (R) of a conductor in ohms can be listed as:</p>
<ul>
<li>The resistivity (ρ) of the material from which the conductor is made.</li>
<li>The total length (L) of the conductor.</li>
<li>The cross-sectional area (A) of the conductor.</li>
<li>The temperature of the conductor.</li>
</ul>
